abstracts.cdata!:
The Environment, Industry and Mining
            Project for Bolivia had the following ratings:  the outcome
            was unsatisfactory, the sustainability was unlikely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both unsatisfactory.  Lessons
            learned indicate that the project has shown problems related
            to the interference of political cycles in project
            implementation as a consequence of the change in
            administrations and political, economic and social unrest.
            The long implementation cycle suffered from a loss of the
            authorities interest and commitment in project objectives
            and execution.  Among the lessons learned are the following:
            (1) Project objectives and components should be simple and
            focused; (2) A comprehensive, rigorous and realistic
            assessment of risks, in terms of country capacity,
            institutional effectiveness, fiduciary aspects, economic and
            financial viability, as well as other exogenous factors
            should be completed, and mitigating strategies and action
            plans to address them as/if they occur, should be
            incorporated to the project design; (3) The team should put
            in place mechanisms to strengthen weak areas and make sure
            that the World Bank Procurement, Financial Management,
            Disbursement guidelines and procedures are fully understood
            by the Borrower; (4) A good monitoring and evaluation system
            with focus on results and outcomes should be an integral
            part of the project design; (5) Bank management should
            ensure continuity in supervision teams to avoid
            interruptions or delays with implementation; (6) Bank
            Supervision of the project should be continuous and
            supported by proper budgets and skill mix; and (7) The
            project team should work with the counterparts to ensure
            that the beneficiaries and stakeholders at large remain
            involved at the project execution stage, so that the project
            does not lose its priority and visibility.
